theories.card_other: A physical quantity that has only magnitude (e.g., mass, time, temperature, speed, energy, distance).
A physical quantity that has both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, acceleration, force, momentum).

Three methods: (1) Triangle method - place vectors head to tail; (2) Parallelogram method - place vectors tail to tail; (3) Component method - resolve into perpendicular components and add algebraically.
A vector with magnitude of exactly 1, used to specify direction. Notation: î (x-direction), ĵ (y-direction), k̂ (z-direction).
A vector with zero magnitude and arbitrary direction. Resultant when equal and opposite vectors are added.
Results in a scalar. Maximum when vectors are parallel (θ = 0°), zero when perpendicular (θ = 90°), used to find work done by force. Commutative: A·B = B·A.

Results in a vector perpendicular to both original vectors. Maximum when vectors are perpendicular (θ = 90°), zero when parallel (θ = 0°). Used to find torque and angular momentum. Direction by right-hand rule. Not commutative: A×B = -B×A.
A body is in equilibrium when it is at rest or moving with constant velocity (zero acceleration). Requires both net force and net torque to be zero.

Stable: Returns to original position when disturbed (center of mass rises). Unstable: Moves away from original position (center of mass falls). Neutral: Remains in new position (center of mass unchanged).
The point where entire weight of a body appears to act. For uniform gravitational field, coincides with center of mass. Object balances if supported at this point.
The point where entire mass of system appears to be concentrated. Moves as if all external forces act at this point. For symmetric uniform bodies, located at geometric center.
Two equal and opposite parallel forces whose lines of action do not coincide. Produces pure rotation without translation. Net force is zero but net torque is not zero.
Perpendicular distance from axis of rotation to line of action of force. Greater moment arm means greater turning effect for same force.
Breaking a vector into perpendicular components. Any vector can be resolved into horizontal and vertical components using trigonometry.
